content.text: Far down in the forest, where the warm sun and the fresh air made a sweet resting-place, grew a pretty little fir-tree.
The situation was beautiful; the sun shone on it, and the wind played with it, and around it stood many larger comrades—pines and firs.
But the little fir-tree was in a great hurry to grow up.
It did not care for the warm sun and the fresh air; it took no notice of the peasant children who ran about chattering when they came to pick strawberries or raspberries.

Often they came with a whole pitcher full, or a long row of berries strung on a straw, and then they would sit down near the little fir-tree and say, "Oh, how pretty and small this one is!" But this the tree did not like to hear at all.
"I wish I were as tall as the others," sighed the little fir-tree.
"Then I could spread out my branches on every side, and look far around me from my topmost bough.

The birds would then build their nests among my branches, and when the wind blew, I could nod as grandly as the others."  The sun shone, and the little hares sprang past; but the fir-tree took no heed of them.
Sometimes in winter, when the snow lay white and glittering on the ground, a hare would come springing along, and jump right over the little tree.
Oh, that made it so angry!
Two winters passed, and when the third came, the tree had grown so tall that the hare was obliged to run round it.
"Oh, grow, grow, grow!
become big and old," thought the tree; "that is the most beautiful thing in the world."  In autumn the woodcutters always came and felled some of the largest trees.

This happened every year, and the young fir-tree, that was now quite well grown, trembled at the sight; for the great, stately trees fell to the earth with a crash, and their branches were cut off, so that the trees looked quite naked, long, and slender—they could hardly be recognized.
Then they were laid upon wagons, and horses dragged them out of the wood. Where were they going?
What would become of them?
In the spring, when the swallows and the storks came, the tree asked them, "Do you know where they were taken?
Have you met them?"  The swallows knew nothing about it, but the stork looked thoughtful, nodded his head, and said, "Yes, I think I know.
I met many new ships as I flew from Egypt; on the ships were stately masts, and I fancy these were the trees.
I assure you they were stately; they smelt so of fir."  "Oh, I wish I were big enough to go on the sea!
What is the sea, and what does it look like?"  "It would take too long to explain," said the stork, and with that he flew away.

"Rejoice in thy youth!" said the sunbeams; "rejoice in thy fresh growth, and in the young life that is within thee!"  And the wind kissed the tree, and the dew wept tears over it, but the fir-tree did not understand.
When Christmas-time approached, quite young trees were felled, sometimes trees that were neither so large nor so old as this fir-tree, who could never rest, and always wanted to be off.
These young trees, which were always the most beautiful, kept their branches; they were laid on wagons, and horses dragged them out of the wood.
"Where are they going?" asked the fir-tree. "They are not taller than I am; indeed, one was much smaller.
And why do they keep all their branches? Where are they going?"  "We know! We know!" chirped the sparrows.
"We have peeped in at the windows in the town below. We know where they are going.
Oh, they are going to where it is as bright and splendid as you can imagine!

We have peeped through the windows, and have seen them planted in the middle of the warm room, and adorned with the most splendid things—gilded apples, honey-cakes, playthings, and many hundreds of candles."  "And then?" asked the fir-tree, trembling in all its branches.
"And then?
What happens then?"  "We did not see any more; but it was incomparably beautiful."  "I wonder if I am destined to make such a brilliant journey!" cried the fir-tree rejoicingly.
"That is even better than crossing the sea! How I long for the time to come!
If it were only Christmas now!
Now I am tall and full-grown, like the others that were led away last year.
Oh, if I were only already on the wagon!
If I were only in the warm room with all the splendor and brightness! And then?
Yes, then something even better, something still more beautiful will come, or why should they adorn me so?
There must be something still grander, still more beautiful—but what? Oh, how I long!

I don’t know myself what is the matter with me!"  "Rejoice with us," said the air and the sunlight; "rejoice in thy fresh youth in the free air!"  But the tree did not rejoice at all; it grew and grew, and was green both winter and summer.
People who saw it said, "What a beautiful tree!" And at Christmas-time it was felled before any of the others.

The axe struck deep into the very pith; the tree fell to the earth with a sigh; it felt a pang—it swooned away—it could not think of any happiness, for it was sad at being separated from its home, from the place where it had sprung up.
It knew that it should never again see the dear old companions, the little bushes and flowers around it, perhaps not even the birds.
The departure was not at all pleasant.
The tree only came to itself when it was unloaded in a yard with other trees, and heard a man say, "This one is splendid!
We don’t want a better."  Then two servants came in gay livery, and carried the fir-tree into a large and splendid saloon.

Portraits were hanging on the walls, and near the white porcelain stove stood great Chinese vases with lions on the covers; there were rocking-chairs, silken sofas, and large tables covered with picture-books and with playthings worth a hundred times a hundred dollars—at least so the children said.
And the fir-tree was stuck upright in a large tub filled with sand; but no one could see that it was a tub, for green cloth was hung all round it, and it stood on a large many-colored carpet.
Oh, how the tree trembled! What was to happen now?
The servants, as well as the young ladies, decorated it.

On one branch they hung little nets cut out of colored paper; every net was filled with sweetmeats; gilded apples and walnuts hung down as if they grew there, and more than a hundred little tapers, red, white, and blue, were fastened to the different boughs.
Dolls that looked exactly like real people—the tree had never seen such before—swung among the foliage, and high on the summit of the tree was fixed a tinsel star.
It was really splendid—beyond description splendid.
"This evening," they all said, "this evening it will shine."  "Oh," thought the tree, "if it were only evening!
If the tapers were but lighted! And then what will happen?
Will the trees come out of the wood to look at me? Will the sparrows fly against the panes?
Shall I grow fast here, and stand adorned winter and summer?"  Yes, it fancied a great deal; but its bark ached with impatience, and that is as bad for a tree as a headache is for us.
At last the tapers were lighted. What a brilliance, what splendor!
The tree trembled so in all its branches that one of the candles set fire to a green twig; it burnt terribly.
"Good heavens!" cried the young ladies, and they quickly put out the fire.
Now the tree might not even tremble. Oh, that was terrible!
It was so afraid of losing any of its splendor, and it was quite bewildered with all the brilliance.
And now the folding doors were thrown open, and a troop of children rushed in as if they would have overturned the tree; the older people came quietly after.
The little ones stood quite silent, but only for a moment; then they shouted till the room rang: they danced round the tree, and one present after another was plucked from it.
"What are they doing?" thought the tree.
"What will happen now?"  And the candles burnt down to the very branches, and as they burnt down they were extinguished, and then the children were allowed to plunder the tree.
Oh, they rushed upon it so that every branch cracked; if it had not been fastened by the top and by the golden star to the ceiling, it would have fallen down.
The children danced about with their pretty toys.
No one looked at the tree except the old nurse, who peeped between the branches, but only to see if there was a fig or an apple left that had been forgotten.
"A story!
A story!" cried the children, and they drew a little fat man toward the tree; and he sat down just beneath it, and said, "Now we are in the green wood, and the tree may listen if it likes.
But I shall only tell one story.

Will you have the one about Ivede-Avede, or the one about Humpty-Dumpty, who fell downstairs, and yet was raised up to honor, and married the princess?"  "Ivede-Avede!" cried some; "Humpty-Dumpty!" cried others; and there was a great crying and shouting.
Only the fir-tree was silent, and thought, "Shall I not be in it?
Shall I have nothing to do?" But it had been in it—it had done what it was there for.
And the man told about Humpty-Dumpty, who fell downstairs, and yet was raised to honor, and married the princess.
And the children clapped their hands, and cried, "Tell another!
Tell another!" For they wanted to hear about Ivede-Avede too; but they only got Humpty-Dumpty.
The fir-tree stood quite silent and thoughtful; never had the birds in the wood told such a tale as that.
"Humpty-Dumpty fell downstairs, and yet he married the princess.
Yes, yes, so goes the world!" thought the fir-tree, and believed it must be true, because such a nice man had told the story.
"Well, who can know?
Perhaps I shall fall downstairs too, and marry a princess!" And it looked forward with joy to the next day, when it would be decked out again with candles and toys, gold and fruit.
"I will not tremble to-morrow," it thought. "I will enjoy all my splendor to the full.
To-morrow I shall hear the story of Humpty-Dumpty again, and perhaps that of Ivede-Avede too."  And the tree stood silent and thoughtful all night.
In the morning the servants and the maid came in. "Now the splendor will begin again," thought the fir-tree.
But they dragged it out of the room, up the stairs, into the garret, and here they put it in a dark corner where no daylight shone.
"What is this?" thought the tree. "What am I to do here?
What shall I hear here?" And it leaned against the wall and thought and thought.
And it had time enough, for days and nights went by, and nobody came up; and when at last somebody came, it was only to put some large boxes in the corner.
Now the tree stood quite hidden; it seemed as if it had been entirely forgotten.
"Now it is winter outside," thought the tree.
"The earth is hard and covered with snow; men cannot plant me now; therefore I must be here till spring comes.
How thoughtful that is! How good men are! If it were not so dark here, and so terribly lonely!
Not even a little hare!
And out in the woods it was so pleasant, when the snow lay there and the hare sprang past; yes, even when it jumped over me; but I did not like it then.
It is really terribly lonely here!"  "Squeak!
Squeak!" said a little mouse at that moment, peeping out; and then another little one came.
They smelt at the fir-tree, and then they crept among the branches.
"It is dreadfully cold," said the little mice. "But for that, it would be very comfortable here.
Don’t you think so, old fir-tree?"  "I am not old at all," said the fir-tree.
"There are many much older than I."  "Do you come from far?" asked the mice; "and do you know anything?
Have you seen the most beautiful places in the world, and can you tell us about them?"  "I know the world very well," said the fir-tree.
"I have seen the warm sun, and the fresh air, and the stars in the sky.
Oh, I have seen many beautiful things!"  "And what is the most beautiful thing you have seen?" asked the mice.

"I have seen a great many beautiful things," said the fir-tree, "but the most beautiful was when I stood in the warm room, and was adorned with candles and toys, and the children came and plundered me.
Then I was very happy."  "That is a very simple story," said the little mice.
"Don’t you know any others?
Can’t you tell us about the woods, and about the places where you grew?"  "No," said the fir-tree.
"We won’t listen to you any more," said the mice, and they went away.

After a while the mice came back, and the fir-tree told them about the time when it was little, and how it had grown up in the woods, and how the birds had sung around it, and how the sun had shone, and the wind had played with it.
"That was very pretty," said the mice.

"But tell us something about the most beautiful thing you have seen."  "I have told you," said the fir-tree, "the most beautiful thing I have seen was when I stood in the warm room, and was adorned with candles and toys, and the children came and plundered me."  "That is a very simple story," said the mice.
"We don’t want to hear any more about that.
Can’t you tell us something about the woods?"  "No," said the fir-tree.
Then the mice went away, and the fir-tree was left alone.
"Well, it is very pleasant when the merry little mice sit around me and listen to what I tell them," thought the fir-tree.
"But I wish the children would come.
They were so happy, and they danced round me, and plucked my branches.

Oh, if I could only see them again!"  But the children did not come, and the fir-tree stood there and thought of its youth in the woods, and of the merry Christmas-eve, and of the little mice who had listened so gladly to the story of Humpty-Dumpty.
"And it is all past!" said the old tree.
"Oh, if I had but rejoiced when I could have done so!
But now it is too late."  Then a servant came and chopped the tree into small pieces; it made quite a heap.
It crackled loudly before the stove, and it sighed deeply; and each sigh was like a little shot.
Then the children who were in the room came and sat before the stove, looked into the fire, and cried, "Piff!

paff!" But at every crack, which was a deep sigh, the tree thought of a summer day in the woods, or of a winter night there when the stars shone; it thought of Christmas-eve, and of Humpty-Dumpty, the only story it had ever heard and knew how to tell—and then the tree was burned.
The boys played in the yard, and the youngest had on his breast the gold star which the tree had worn on its happiest evening.
Now that was past, and the tree was past, and the story is past too—past, like all stories.
